titleInfo.title: United We Consume, Create, Manage
titleInfo.subTitle: Exploring and Defining Consumer Generated Branding

mods:mods.abstract: What does the future look like for consumers and brands? The 2020 COVID-19 global pandemic added new uncertainties and brought new insights and geared consumers and brands to the real essentials of the 'human touch' in marketing communications. When the novel coronavirus made the world stand still, marketers and consumers finally had a chance to take notice of the sea of sameness in advertising and branding. The question remained: What is the role of the empowered, hyper-connected consumer in building the future of branding? Against this backdrop, this dissertation research aimed to bridge the gap between the rhetoric of consumer involvement in branding and the reality of its utility. Using a grounded theory approach and guided by the identity-based brand management approach and the national cultural dimensions, this dissertation research aimed to establish the definition of consumer generated branding from a cross-national and cross-cultural perspective. In doing so, the secondary research objective was to define and identify different forms of sponsored and non-sponsored consumer generated branding initiatives. To this end, this dissertation research utilized an innovative triangulation of a mixed-methods research design, including qualitative semi-structured interviews and observational methods comprising open card sorting, think-aloud protocol, and web-based real-time heatmap visualization. The participants included forty-four consumers and brand practitioners from the U.S. and India. Combining the insights from the qualitative interviews and the observational methods, the key academic contribution of this dissertation research was that it helped bridging the gap in the literature by proposing a contemporary and phenomenologically grounded understanding of consumer generated branding. The key managerial contribution of this dissertation was that it offered fresh avenues of co-creating consumer-centric, sustainable, and inclusive marketing communication, and also provided meaningful observations on the ever-evolving consumer-brand relationships, within the new and emerging media environments. This dissertation research was more than an invitation to think differently, it was a clarion call to actionâ€“to help create a new world of possibilities through brand value co-creation.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the School of Communication in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
branding, consumer behavior, consumer generated branding, consumer generated content, digital marketing, user generated content
Juliann Cortese, Professor Directing Dissertation; Vanessa Dennen, University Representative; Stephen McDowell, Committee Member; Jaejin Lee, Committee Member.
